p: According to [ 34], excludability creates and sustains effective collective action (i.e. use of taboos, norms and values) in the management of CPRs, such as medicinal plants. Participatory formulation and implementation of decisions concerning environmental resources, a form of collective action, is among the sustainable solutions on governance with complex environmental challenges [ 50]. This includes mechanisms for controlling access and appropriation or excludability. Collective action is enhanced when PRs and the institution for its enforcement are neither challenged nor undermined [ 51].
